dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High over the city on a bright Sunday morning, the sun pounding its way through the orange haze of smog. As we descend toward the clots of traffic blocking the streets: the sounds of a Mass being sung.

dialogues.speaker: A CATHOLIC CHURCH
dialogues.text: The big wooden doors open to release the parishioners inside. Feature a tall, lanky 18-YEAR-OLD. Holding his GIRLFRIEND'S hand, anxious for Sunday to really begin. They don't notice the traffic suddenly thin, like a faucet's been cranked down. They move toward a Mercedes 500. As a CHAUFFEUR holds the back door open for them...

dialogues.speaker: A GRAND MARQUIS
dialogues.text: Squeals around the corner, lurches to a stop alongside the Mercedes. FOUR MEN get out flashing  badges. In a moment they're hustling Eighteen toward the car, stiff- arming the chauffeur. As the girlfriend  cries and the gossip among the parishioners begins... The Grand Marquis pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shove eighteen down to the floor of the backseat. These guys are not the police. A switchblade is flicked open. Practiced hands slit the boy's Sunday suit from the base of his neck to his heels. Eighteen yelps as the blade draws blood across one calf. Duct tape is wrapped around his hands, eyes, and head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Marquis is parked across from another CAR. FOUR NEW GUYS wait as Eighteen is hauled out of the Marquis. His clothes drop away like a snake shedding its skin. He stands naked, bound and blind. Eighteen is handed over from one group to the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone rings. A bomb going off. Eighteen's distraught FATHER (family photos of the boy on the wall) answers. Work in Progress 2/10/03 REVERSE TO REVEAL a battery of POLICE and NEGOTIATORS in the room with him. One of them listens in, waves fingers at him as the negotiations begin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wall smeared with God-knows-what. Facing   it, Eighteen stands naked blindfolded and shivering. The   back of his leg still bleeds. He shifts nervously as a   little JACK RUSSELL TERRIER eagerly licks the blood off  his calf. A MAN ('The Dreamer'), we don't see his face, negotiates by cell phone. Voice calm. As he runs numbers, he slaps his thigh. Jack Russell trots over, gets an ear scratched. At a motion from the man, Eighteen is taken down to the ground. Straddled by two men, his head is mummified in tape leaving one ear exposed. CUT TO T.V. - Rosanna Garcia Guerrero, editor of REFORMA newspaper, being interviewed, "...organized crime syndicates...growth of kidnapping in Mexico over the last two years."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a hand removes a ziplock baggie from the mailbox. A glimpse of something we don't want to see. An ear partially obscured by sweating plastic and a blood smear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MERCEDES driving around the square, Eighteen's father waving a white shirt out the window like a surrender flag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Footbridge over railway sandwiched between freeway. Empty train blazes through. Dangerous, deserted downtown neighborhood. Looks more like "war torn Beirut", burnt out cars and trash. The 18 year old's father, naked to the waist, walks from the family Mercedes over the footbridge carrying a pillowcase full of cash to a semi- derelict car on the opposite side with a white piece of fabric taped in the rear windshield and trunk open. He slams the pillow case in the trunk and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUSH HOUR. A red stream of headlights separated from a white stream of taillights by a narrow median. Work in Progress 2/10/03 HORNS blare as a CAR stops. Eighteen, still blindfolded, is dumped on the median. The car pulls away. He stands there in the whirlwind. Pathetically SCREAMING for help. More horns, shouts, no help. END MAIN TITLES.   Goes to black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ezekiel 25:17 Blessed is he who in the name of charity and good will shepherds the weak through the valley of darkness for he is truly his brother's keeper and the finder of lost children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samuel Valencia Ramos and his lawyer Jordan Kalfus in the privacy of an alcove table. Jordan is well heeled, well connected and well oiled. In that order. Samuel, at 40, already has the patrician look that has served the male members of his family for generations. They discuss the kidnapping, a headline on the paper Jordan tosses aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family paid the ransom and he was returned two days later. (laughs; chews)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His father still hasn't gotten up the nerve to ask him if they fucked him up the ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now every mother with money in Mexico City wants bigger and better bodyguards. My own wife included.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If she pisses you off, you get another one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs grimly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what she told me last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samuel sits at his baby    grand piano playing a gentle rendering of 'Delibes'.     His American wife LISA stands away from him. Just the     sight of her back reveals a pitch perfect petulance.    She tells him: Work in Progress 2/10/03

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man's worth can be judged by what he has or what he owes. Only the amount matters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And bankruptcy. Where will that put me in the social strata?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm only asking for one thing. And it's not an extravagance. It's not even for me; it's for our daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our daughter. She turns at that: a woman so beautiful it nearly hurts to look at her. She stares, plays him like Chinese Checkers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our child's safety is at stake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stops playing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These people are professionals. They don't waste their time taking children whose fathers are virtually bankrupt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samuel, it is not something we should skimp on. A bodyguard's presence in the car or outside the school was at least some form of deterrent. Now he's gone, I feel totally exposed. She just stares at him.    He melts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jordan smiles at his client, enjoys seeing him squirm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I care about Pinta. She'll be as beautiful as her mother one day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?   And if she was ugly? Samuel rolls his eyes. Jordan laughs.       Beheading two cigars, he passes one to Samuel. Work in Progress 2/10/03                                5

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All my clients have kidnap and ransom insurance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a policy, AIG. It covers me and my family and when it runs out in sixty days, without a bodyguard, I will not be able to renew it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you need to please Lisa. An ass like that is hard to find. Good bodyguards are even harder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know! I just had to let one go because I couldn't afford him! Jordan lights his cigar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need a bodyguard of some description. It's a dangerous world we live in. But you will get what you pay for. He doesn't need to be Superman, does he? Can you go fifteen grand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a year?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a few months. Hire someone cheap. You have to have a bodyguard to keep the insurance. Then fire him for incompetence. The important thing is Lisa's daughter will return to school. Samuel finally follows the logic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Lisa will be able to save face.    We won't be the only family without a bodyguard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her beauty fucks with your mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For an American she understands this country very well. Work in Progress 2/10/03

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She understands men. As Samuel puffs his cigar in satisfaction...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a 747 is towed by in the background, a MAN strides at us. CREASY. Even in movement, he has a stillness, an air of isolation. He's set apart from other living things. He wears dark sunglasses, carries a well-worn leather bag. Inscrutable. Disconnected. A bit frightening. The discipline of a soldier. The independence of a gunslinger. Automatic baggage teller (Red Light, Green Light). Creasy feeds the machine with his perforated customs card. Light flashes RED.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMS MAN
dialogues.text: He flips through Creasy's passport. Even the stamps have stamps. Thailand. Somalia. Cuba. Columbia. Hong Kong. Saudi Arabia. Every country in Europe. Guy's been around. Customs looks up from the ink blue American Eagle to the deep matte black of Creasy's sunglasses. NOTE:    Italics denotes the lines spoken in Spanish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you coming from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: South America.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you staying in Mexico?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on to Juarez.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a friend there. Customs looks at Creasy a moment. He doesn't look like a man who has 'friends'. Finally, customs smiles. Work in Progress 2/10/03

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot see your eyes, Senor. Creasy slips off the sunglasses. His eyes are deserted. Inevitable. Customs can only look into them a moment. He indicates for Creasy to put his bags on a conveyor belt leading to an X-ray machine. Creasy lifts his bag onto the conveyor. The official hits the start button. The bag drives forward towards the X-ray machine. Creasy pauses, then offers up a license from his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Senor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a permit to carry a gun in Columbia. The gun you're about to find in that suitcase. Polaroid FLASH Shot of Creasy straight on.     Shot of Creasy profile. FLASH.   Fingers being fingerprinted. JUMPCUTS - suitcase being stripped and ripped (MIDNIGHT EXPRESS), pack of Marlboro, bottle of Jack Daniels, glimpse a weathered Bible (New Testament), intercut with seven pieces of blue steel separated in different parts of the bag, ie. toiletries, underwear, lining of suitcase. The seven pieces laid together look remarkably like a well travelled Sig Sauer 226. Creasy smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six Japanese BUSINESSMEN jabber on cellphones. PAUL RAYBURN sits up front trying not to spill coffee on the mini Uzi cradled in his lap. As his own cell phone rings, he answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rayburn here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creasy on payphone. Work in Progress 2/10/03

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did Mexican Customs start getting smart? RAYBURN's SUV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creasy???   Where the fuck are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here. RAYBURN's SUV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, I'm here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in a Customs holding tank in Mexico City International. Bring a bunch of cash... about 5K. I'm going to need it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rayburn has 5K U.S. dollars laid out on      the desk bet him, the Customs official, and Creasy.       The remains the suitcase are spread around the room.       The main offender, the gun being front and center      next to the cash. Looks like the official is going       to fold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is going to cost you big time. INT. STRIP BAR - Rethink Location A stripper does a half hearted grind as Rayburn and Creasy sit at the bar sharing a bottle of 'Jack'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a secondary search and you had a gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen it was a calculated risk. I've done it a million times and never got caught.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything happens once if you live long enough. Work in Progress 2/10/03

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't make sense to x-ray your bags coming off the plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Mexico, they do everything backwards. Creasy hits the 'Jack'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't give me that bullshit. Creasy changes subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how's business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Japanese are here in a big way. Cheap labor. Factory space. But they feel a lot safer living over the border in El Paso. I ferry 'em back and forth. They think I'm John-fucking-Wayne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But don't you stay in El Paso?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck, I love Mexico.   I live like a king down here. Creasy takes a look around the Seedy Bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, right...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, like you haven't been in worse places.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And a level five shithole is better than a level six. Your logic's inescapable. Rayburn laughs. Creasy takes the bottle.     Creasy's han is mottled by old burn marks. Work in Progress 2/10/03

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You been working?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for eight months. I was in Columbia looking around, but, nothing seemed interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long you staying, Crease?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got no plans, Rayburn, Nothing on. Just wanted to see you, how you were. Came by on impulse. Rayburn studies his friend a beat, just seeing the cracks that weren't there last time they met.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did something on impulse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything happens once if you live long enough. Creasy smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine-year-old PINTA MARTIN RAMOS stares out at the garden, a bit like Creasy, but only a ten yard stare. Pinta's eyes brim with life. She folds her hands, closes her eyes, prays. 'Chopin' drifts up from downstairs. Samuel on the baby grand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear God. I do not ask for health. Or wealth. People ask you so often that you can't have any left. Give me God what you still have. Give me what no one else asks for. Amen. Pinta grabs a battered old TEDDY BEAR and climbs into bed. She pulls the covers up, looks over as her door opens. Lisa enters.    Pinta is her daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should be sleeping, baby. Work in Progress 2/10/03

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying, mom. Lisa strokes her head, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good news.     You're going back to school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sits up; excited)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samuel is going to hire a new bodyguard. It may take a few days, but you're going back. Pinta lets it sink in.   Lisa kisses her goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could he speak English?     Emilio couldn't speak English. LISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll see. And thank your father in the morning. A man always needs to be thanked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four SUV's blast along a desert highway on their way to pick up some Japanese businessmen. Rayburn rides shotgun, Creasy in the back. Rayburn looks like he slept in his clothes. Creasy looks crisp and clean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, a bodyguard. Creasy looks at him blankly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Spanish is good enough.     You certainly look the part.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're crazy. People would hire a has- been, Ray? A drunk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you'd have to keep it under control. Work in Progress 2/10/03

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what if, just say, there was a kidnap attempt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do your best. They won't be paying you enough to perform miracles. Creasy just shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not exactly a scam, Crease. Even at half speed you're pretty damn good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bodyguard has to be close to someone all the time. Willing to talk. I'm not good at that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you'll be the silent type.    People will appreciate that. Creasy shakes his head, looks out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came to visit you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit. I've known you fifteen years. You don't visit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bodyguard... Who's the guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samuel Ramos.    Owns one of the plants in Juarez. The    Jap car industry is in the toilet. He's    trying to persuade Ford to partner with   him. I think he's in trouble. He    asked me if I knew anyone he could trust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, now you think I can be trusted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a job, Creasy. Breathe some air. Then decide if you want to... stick around or not. Work in Progress 2/10/03 Rayburn throws him a VHS from the glove box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Instructional tape on what I tell my clients about bodyguarding. Creasy looks back at Rayburn who's just a little too perceptive for comfort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dark Mercedes maneuvers the turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creasy at the wheel.    Samuel sits in the back.   Studyi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You drive easily. Smoothly. Creasy doesn't answer, just drives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you provided with a gun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show me, please. Creasy takes his right hand off the wheel, reaches under his jacket and passes back a beat-to-shit looking PISTOL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine millimeter. A Sig Sauer 226.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you used this type before? Creasy just nods.   Doesn't like the show and tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it loaded?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's loaded. Samuel hands back the gun. Work in Progress 2/10/03

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will meet my wife first. She would like it if you are presentable, polite and respectful. You'll be the fifth candidate she's seen this week. Samuel flips through a manila folder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your resume is impressive. Nine years in the Army. Extensive counter terrorism work. I shouldn't be able to afford you in my current state. What's the catch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (honest)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How does it affect you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My coordination. Reaction time. If top professionals try to kidnap your daughter, the service will be on par with the pay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what if amateurs try it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll probably kill them.   Is that likely?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. And no one is to know of your drinking problem. That includes my wife. As they pull up to the Ramos' impressive hacienda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Lisa is flipping through TV channels; Sky News, CNN, etc... Each one showing some terrorist act - West Bank protest, Madrid car bombing. Samuel and Creasy, meanwhile, enter behind her.      She clicks it off, looks back at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The world of our children.   How dare they? Work in Progress 2/10/03

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's war. The weakest suffer the most.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're American.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So are you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (introducing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife, Mr. Creasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa Martin Ramos, Mr. Creasy. Lisa steps over, shakes Creasy's hand.    Gives him a qui once over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like a drink? Creasy doesn't hesitate, doesn't look at Samuel and has no irony in his answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.     Scotch and a little water. She steps to the bar to make it.

dialogues.speaker: CREASY
dialogues.text: Slightly sinister.   Watching from the frame of the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've done much of this work before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never. Samuel sells, covers for Creasy's reticence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has experience in related work.     A great deal of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any family, Mr. Creasy? Creasy hesitates for an imperceptible beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   I do not have family. Work in Progress 2/10/03 And then, somehow, Creasy is aware of being watched. eyes flicker over, just in time to see...

dialogues.speaker: PINTA
dialogues.text: Crouched low. In the doorway. She stares back at him a beat, then disappears around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: SITTING ROOM
dialogues.text: Creasy frowns.    Lisa steps over with Creasy's drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. She makes a point of looking into his eyes. Creasy looks back into hers with complete indifference, something she has not experienced even from dying men. She abruptly turns away.    Confused for a moment. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pinta! A few moments and Pinta arrives.       'Cool Hand Pinta'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, mom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Mr. Creasy. Pinta walks over and very formally holds out her hand. Creasy shakes it. An odd beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pinta, show him to his room. Samuel reacts.    Creasy got the job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This way, Mr. Creasy. What an actress. As he follows her out.        Samuel sit his baby grand and begins to play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's nice he's American.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's fantastic. Work in Progress 2/10/03

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You realize that you've brought a killer into the house. Samuel is stopped short by that one.    She steps over an kisses her husband on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.     I feel better now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pinta leads the way. All enthusiasm, away from her parents. A 150 pound black German Shepherd greets them. Sniffs Creasy's pant leg, unsure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you like dogs, Mr. Creasy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they like me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank doesn't take to most people.       Do you speak German?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in German)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ein Klines Bisschen.     [A tiny bit.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank only responds to commands in German. He was trained in Frankfurt. My Dad loves the idea of having a dog around, but hates the fact he lives inside. Creasy follows her.   Frank pads along after them.

dialogues.speaker: CREASY'S ROOM
dialogues.text: Not like downstairs, but comfortable enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We fixed the room up two weeks ago.       Mom and I. It's nicer than before. Creasy takes a stroll around it, ignoring her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got a CD player if you like music. I like music a lot. Work in Progress 2/10/03 CAW! Creasy looks over at a CAGE on a stand holding a MACAW. It tilts its head at the big man. A TV and VHS machine in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's 'Bird.' Emilio forgot to take him with when he left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Emilio?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My last bodyguard. He drove me to school in the morning and picked me up in the afternoon. Finally Creasy turns, looks at her hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here for you? Pinta smiles huge, nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In between you can take Mom shopping and to lunch. Does that sound alright, Mr. Creasy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creasy.   Just call me Creasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (big grin)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creasy... Frank's tail wags imperceptibly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like he approves of you. And then, walking on air, she's out the door. Creasy sets up his room with meticulous precision that comes from years in the military. Front and center he arranges his shrine: an almost empty bottle of scotch and a glass (engraved from an earlier encounter) next to a pack of Marlboros and his weathered Zippo. Then, his beaten up gun and holster. A well-travelled New Testament is placed in the drawer.

dialogues.speaker: CREASY'S BAG
dialogues.text: Work in Progress 2/10/03 He reaches in between the shirts, pulls out a fresh bottle of scotch. He breaks the seal, unscrews the cap. He pours a double... triple... wait, what do you call a full glass of scotch? CAW!   The macaw squawks it's disapproval. He ejects the shell from the breach of the 9mm, tries to catch it on the back of his hand. An old game with himself. His hand is too shaky. The bullet bounces off, hits the floor. Creasy picks it up. Ejecting the magazine, he starts to oil the weapon. CAW! As the macaw squawks, Creasy looks up. It doesn't feel like this relationship is going to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A battered TEDDY BEAR watches as Lisa sits on the foot of the bed, tucks Pinta in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: School tomorrow, baby. Pinta smiles, happy at the thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like him, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's like a great big bear. (a secret smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Creasy bear'... Lisa smiles, kisses her goodnight.    As she starts out..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's something about him. Lisa turns, looks back at her daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he's been sick. He's alright now, but I think he's been very, very sick. Work in Progress 2/10/03

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, think about going to sleep.   Good night, baby. Lisa exits.   Pinta looks over at the battered teddy bear

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like you, a big old bear.

dialogues.speaker: CREASY
dialogues.text: In his room. Tests his mag spring with his thumb, begins loading up. The full magazine joins with those already loaded. Another glass of scotch is poured. Creasy's hands oil the holster. The Sig Sauer is slipped in. The holster is hung over the corner post of the bed. A map is flattened. Creasy's finger traces various routes, pencils them in. From the house to Pinta's school. The macaw squawks again. Creasy steps over, takes the cage and carries it to the open window. He opens the cage door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now's your chance. The bird flies, disappears out the window. INT.   LISA & SAMUEL'S BEDROOM - NIGHT Spent, glistened in sweat, the couple lay side by side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She likes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creasy.   Pinta likes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pinta loves school. She'd like Count Dracula is he took her back there. Work in Progress 2/10/03 Lisa just smiles, knows her daughter better.

dialogues.speaker: CREASY'S ROOM
dialogues.text: Creasy's drinking in the dark next to the window, listening to the sounds of Mexico City at night. The empty scotch glass is set down.    Ominously sober.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brushing her hair, Pinta wanders to the window at the sound of a car hood closing. Creasy is down below going over the car; a dark BLUE MERCEDES. As he checks underneath... The "Car Wash Guy", Pedro, trying to engage Creasy. Frank looks on, seems like he disapproves of Pedro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creasy sits grimly behind the wheel. Pinta exuberant beside him. Traveling route number one from home base to school. Pinta looks at Creasy's hands on the wheel. The back of the right one is swirled with scars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you from, Creasy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The United States.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.    But which state? Creasy checks the rearview mirror. A banged up white TOYOTA COROLLA pulls out behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No state in particular. Pinta frowns; this is going to take some work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mom and me are from Houston, Texas. Have you been there? Creasy has his eyes on the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Work in Progress 2/10/03

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can drive and talk at the same time, can't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turns left)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking for potential. Creasy checks the mirror. The white Corolla continues the way it was going. False alarm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Potential?     I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Places where the road bends, places away from buildings, places where the traffic thins out. But you don't have to understand. I do. So no talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you going to quit?     My last bodyguard quit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me guess, you wouldn't stop talking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone gave him more money than we could.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a bargain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Being black, is that a positive or negative for a bodyguard in Mexico?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time will tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There were 24 kidnappings in Mexico City in the last six days. Four a day. What do you think about that, Mr. Creasy? Work in Progress 2/10/03

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty impressive. Maybe I need to up my fee or get a larger gun. She looks at his scared right hand, then him.     All curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creasy pulls the Mercedes up out front.   He notes the high walls, the heavy gates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beep the horn. Creasy hits it. A beat and then a   shutter opens at eye level. Pinta waves from the car.    A moment later the gate is being slowly pushed open by  an old WATCHMAN. Creasy drives in toward a rambling,  ivy-clad building se in spacious grounds.

dialogues.speaker: COURTYARD
dialogues.text: Creasy parks, get out of the car.   He looks around, appraising the lay of the land.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it beautiful? Pinta's name is called. An elderly gray-haired NUN walks over from the entrance. Pinta runs over, kiss her warmly on both cheeks, then leads her toward Creasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sister Anna, the headmistress. (to nun; proudly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Creasy, my bodyguard. Sister Anna shakes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Creasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Sister, he told me just to call him Creasy. He's American. From no state in particular.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must look after our Pinta. We're so happy to have her back in school. Run along now, Pinta. Pinta waves goodbye, bounds away.   They watch her go. Work in Progress 2/10/03

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's late, Mr. Creasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I've got to get used to the routes. I -- It won't happen again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No offense, but I'm sorry that your profession needs to exist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So am I, Sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you ever see the hand of God in what you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for a long time, sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bible says, "Be not overcome of evil, but overcome evil with good."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romans, chapter 12, verse 21. Sister Anna is impressed.   She nods her 'props' to Creasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the sheep that got lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creasy pulls out, starts down the street. He's only gone a hundred meters when SIRENS kick up. A police car behind him. Creasy shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we go again. Creasy pulls over, digs around the front seat as TWO SLOPPY COPS head over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you speak English, Senor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   And Spanish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have an identification? Work in Progress 2/10/03 Creasy hands them his PASSPORT and a printed LETTER. A legitimate firearms license for bodyguard work witnessed by Rayburn. Creasy deliberately puts one hand on the steering wheel, then the other. Minimizing the confrontation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a temporary license for the gun I'm carrying. I just went through all of this at the airport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six Japanese BUSINESSMEN jabber on cellphones. Rayburn's daily routine. He sits up front an Uzi cradled in his lap. As his own cell phone rings, he answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rayburn here. Creasy, what's up? (listens; laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POLICE LINE-UP WALL - As Creasy's MUG SHOT is flashed. CREASY'S HAND - As he's fingerprinted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's still ink on my fingers from last week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got tossed. Don't trust the cops, especially the Judicials. (listens; laughs again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creasy slams a Jack and Coke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creasy striding, the frivolous shoppers like another species as he moves through them. Might as well wear a shark fin. He spots something: a MUSIC STORE. Work in Progress 2/10/03

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creasy finds the section he's looking for, searches a rack. There. As he pulls a particular CD, we are not privy to what it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creasy waits, smoking a Marlboro light, separate from the other drivers and bodyguards. The bodyguards stand together sharing cigarettes and stories. Give him a share of unfriendly looks. Creasy could care less. The doors open and the children pour out. PINTA exits, a huge grin as she spots Creasy. Creasy palms the Marlboro. The frown on his might as well be chiseled in marble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pinta rides shotgun alongside Creasy.     She looks out t window, realizes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're taking a different way home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. Pinta thinks about it, realizes what he's doing, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand.     Smart. No answer from Creasy.     It's hard not to feel foolish around this kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you like school, Creasy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why not? Creasy's hoping she'll just shut up. Work in Progress 2/10/03

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't a school like yours and there was no Sister Anna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you were unhappy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Being unhappy is a state of mind.   I never thought about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... Pinta watches Creasy a moment, trying to figure a way in. She looks at his scarred right hand on the wheel. Then, as she reaches out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to... And touches it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...your hand? Creasy gives her a look, devoid of humanity for an instant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more questions. When he speaks again he's colder; he's decided something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not paid to be your friend.   I'm paid to protect you. They drive on in silence. Creasy finally glances over. Pinta stares straight ahead, her chin quivering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exasperated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And don't start crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not crying. But she is.   As Creasy stops at a red light... Work in Progress 2/10/03

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, this is the way I am.   I don't like questions. I -- And she's out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. Creasy shoulders open his door, bolts out.

dialogues.speaker: INTERSECTION
dialogues.text: Creasy has barely straightened himself and Pinta is already getting back in the car. This time in the backseat. Creasy sighs. The light goes green.     Scooters whine aw and horns blare.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: Creasy sits back behind the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can take me home now, Mr. Creasy. Creasy looks back at her, but she stares straight ahead. As the chorus of horns continues, Creasy continues drivin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creasy sits at the table   with the old gardener GOMEZ (we've seen him trimming   hedges and such in earlier exteriors). Gomez's just    cleaned his plate and is goin after any remnants with a   crust of bread. Creasy hasn't touched his. MARIA, the cook, enters.    As she clocks Creasy's plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Chopin' drifts across the courtyard. Samuel is a very accomplished player. Creasy sits in a chair in the twilight by the window, a glass of scotch in his hand. A knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in. The door opens.    It's Lisa. Work in Progress 2/10/03

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Creasy, I wanted to make sure you have everything you need.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is the food alright?    Maria tells me that you didn't eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The food's fine. Sometimes I don't eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It insults Maria. Slip it to the dog if you have to... Do you mind if I talk to you for a moment? He shakes his head. Lisa glides into the room like a dancer, sits down at the foot of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you getting along with Pinta?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll be okay once she realizes I'm not a new toy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, she told me.   Do you have children, Mr. Creasy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should know they're tenacious when they want something. And Pinta wants to be friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're paying me to protect her, not amuse her. Right? A beat and then Lisa nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. Maybe this isn't going to work. Maybe you should ask your husband to hire someone... more sociable. Work in Progress 2/10/03

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you're right. You were hired to protect her, that's enough. I'm confident you'll do that. Lisa stands, is about to start out when she sees his gun and holster hanging from the corner of the bed. It gives her pause. Something sexy about it and Creasy's proximity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't realize you had a gun.    I know that's silly to say. Creasy doesn't answer, just watches her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It makes it all seem so serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is serious, Mrs. Ramos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, it's Lisa... I'll be coming with you tomorrow. I have lunch with friends. Finally, Lisa just shrugs and disappears out the door. Creasy slugs down a gulp of scotch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pinta, blankets up, teddy bear beside her, says her prayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me God what you still have.    Give me what no one else asks for. Then, she listens as Linda Ronstadt's "Blue Bayou" starts to drift through the open window, down from the room above.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I'm going back someday, come what may, to Blue Bayou..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands in the dark, in front of the glow of the stereo. The empty bag from the record store. This is the CD he bought. As the song ends, Creasy hits the back- up button. "Blue Bayou" begins again. Creasy takes the 9mm from its holster. As he sits back in his chair... Work in Progress 2/10/03

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pinta listens to the music, figures a way to dance to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creasy sits in the dark with his 'Blue Bayou'. Creasy does not look right. Holding the 9mm, he ejects the round, tries to catch it on the back of his hand. No good. He chambers another round.     Tries again.   Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I'll never be blue, my dreams come true, on Blue Bayou...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pinta still dancing, finding a way to be with Creasy whether he knows it or not. Frank, the dog, watches her every move, perplexed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the song repeats, Creasy chambers yet another round. Feels like he misses a beat as he loads one shell into the chamber. Pinta sings along oblivious. Suddenly the barrel is at his forehead and the trigger has been pulled. No gun shot. A click. Hammer against shell. Creasy is confused. He ejects the shell and catches it in the palm of his hand. Macro photograph / a small dimpl on the back of the shell is the only evidence of his actions. Pinta still dances. INT.   RAYBURN'S BEDROOM - MEXICO CITY - NIGHT 3.A.M. Rayburn in bed with his beautiful 19-year-old Mexican WIFE and their four-year-old SON. As she leans down to kiss her son, a cellphone rings. Rayburn looks over at the nightstand. FIVE CELLPHONES there, one of them ringing. Rayburn finds it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rayburn...    Creasy! What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creasy stands at the edge of the drive, the house dark behind him. On his cell phone. Work in Progress 2/10/03

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, have you ever had a nine millimeter round that just didn't go off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rayburn pulling away, sitting on the edge of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean a misfire?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean nothing. The hammer came down and nothing happened. Dimple on the primer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've heard of it. Never happened to me though. Maybe the firing pin's off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe... Creasy is troubled about it all to say the least.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like we always used to say: a bullet always tells the truth. What were you shooting at? Creasy doesn't answer.    He holds the bullet up, looks a it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (focusing; concerned)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creasy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry I woke you, Ray. Creasy clicks off the phone. He starts back toward the house, but stops short again. There she is. Pinta. Standing in the window of her room. She's been watching him. It's like Creasy seeing her for the first time. And she's been watching him forever. No easy answer for it. They're connected somehow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fingers putting the special bullet into an old matchbox. It takes it place of honor front and center on the shrine. Next to the Marlboros and scotch. The New Testament is set down nearby. Work in Progress 2/10/03 CU - Creasy asleep in his bed for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silent Creasy driving. Lisa and Pinta in the back. Creasy steals a look in the mirror. Pinta stares straight ahead. But when Creasy looks away, Pinta steals a look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the mercedes crosses an intersection, a white TOYOTA COROLLA turns right, pulls in thirty meters behind it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creasy clocks the Corolla, frowns. He pulls a piece of paper from his pocket. But nothing to write with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pinta, do you have a pencil?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I go to school, don't I? Sarcasm. He stays calm, doesn't let on what he's thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please? Her little hand comes over the top of the seat with a pencil. Creasy takes it, slows to let the Corolla catch up. He squints into the mirror to read the plate. Lisa is oblivious, but as Pinta looks back over her shoulder... BRAKE LIGHTS up ahead. Creasy lurches to a stop.    The Corolla swerves around them disappears ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The traffic takes some getting used to. As Creasy cranes for a view, another WHITE Corolla comes by headed the opposite way. They're everywhere. This relaxes Creasy's paranoia. As he laughs to himself. Work in Progress 2/10/03

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pull in through the gates. The Mercedes parks; Creasy gets out. Pinta kisses her mother on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget your towel. Pinta gets out with book bag and her      towel. As she starts to walk past Creasy without a      word, he holds her pencil. She holds up, shows him       a SECOND PENCIL continues on her way. Doesn't need       him.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: Creasy gets back in, starts away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has swimming practice today.    You'll need to pick her up at the pool. Creasy just nods. He doesn't want anything to do with Lisa either. Thoughtful, Lisa looks out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I talked to her. She understands.     She won't bother you anymore. As Creasy just drives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creasy waits in the street, stands by the Mercedes. He checks his watch, looks around. The minutes do not pass quickly. He looks over as the restaurant door opens and Lisa exits with Jordan Kalfus and his Latin wife EVELYN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sees him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creasy! (stepping over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meet Jordan and Evelyn. Creasy nods.    They study him with interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're the bodyguard? (Creasy nods again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You used to be, what did they used to call it, a soldier of fortune? Work in Progress 2/10/03 Jordan doesn't quite hide his disdain. Creasy nods a final time, lets his eyes drift to a 1000 yard stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giggles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does he talk? As Lisa gives her a dirty look, Evelyn whispers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's sexy... Jordan looks in the direction Creasy looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see any danger out there? (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fear's worse than the reality. Just a blankness from Creasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always wanted to ask a bodyguard, would you take a bullet for your employer, for Samuel? A condescending smile as Jordan awaits his answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't hired to guard Mr. Ramos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Pinta then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jordan!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If something happened, my reaction would be to fight to protect her. I have skills in that respect. Pinta would benefit by the fact that... I'm a soldier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of an answer is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The answer is the truth.   The question is foolish. Lisa smiles at the answer, kisses Jordan on the cheek. Work in Progress 2/10/03

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jordan, thank you for the lovely lunch. I promise not to let Evelyn spend too much. Evelyn doesn't see it, but Creasy does. Jordan just lets his fingers trace the top of Lisa's ass. As she and Evelyn head for the car, Creasy is there to open the door.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: Creasy gets behind the wheel. Pulls into traffic. As he goes, he checks the rear view mirror. Jordan remains standing on the curb watching the car pull away. Something odd about it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loud. Chaotic. Reminiscent     of a lunatic asylum. Creas arrives at the public pool.    A practice. Several bodyguards gather at one end   of the pool. Give Creasy a less than friendly look. As    he looks for Pinta... A GUN goes off. Sees: The smoke from the starting pistol as the SWIMMERS splash into the water. He sees Pinta in the pool. The fifty yard dash. She's in fifth. Then fourth. Creasy walks along beside her. Third. Second and closing. And at the wall, still second. She surfaces, frustrated.    As she sees Creasy there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creasy drives. Pinta in back, writing in her notebook. Not speaking, but a weird sort of harmony. Finally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once I get in the water but not starting off. By the time I catch up, it's too late. She keeps writing.   The number "2" over and over. Work in Progress 2/10/03

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creasy sits in his chair drinking scotch.     All alone needless to say. Creasy takes the instructional VHS on bodyguards that Rayburn gave him and plugs it into the VCR. It's in Japanese. Shakes his head. He switches off the VCR and surfs the TV channels instead. Sees talk show with the editor of REFORMA newspaper, ROSANNA GUERRERO, talking about organized crime in Mexico. From out the window, a CAW, then again.     Yet again. Finally, Creasy stands goes to the window. He leans out, sees Pinta's window across the lawn from him. Pinta standing on the terrace. Another CAW. Creasy decides to play.    He CAWS in return. Pinta looks around.    Creasy does a pretty good impersonation. Hears Pinta CAW again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey... Pinta... She looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calling for Emilio's macaw.    I thought I heard him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think he'll come back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.    Did you hear him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you think he got out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I let him go. Work in Progress 2/10/03

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's better to be free, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.   Actually, he was driving me crazy. Creasy disappears back inside. Pinta smiles big before letting the stick drop to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got you to talk, Creasy bear. Blue Bayou plays.   Pinta now listens to Creasy's sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...I'm so lonesome all the time, since I left my baby behind, on Blue Bayou."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A DRIVER gets Samuel's and Lisa's luggage into a car. They're on their way, kissing Pinta goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll call you from Detroit, baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to miss Mexican Halloween. The Day of the Dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You enjoy it for us, Pinta. Lisa gives her a look. Don't make this harder than it has to be. Finally, Pinta nods. Creasy waits quite a discreet distance away by the Mercedes. She steps over, stops to wave goodbye one last time, then gets in back. As Creasy shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creasy drives, glances in the mirror at Pinta in the back seat. She wipes away a tear just as it forms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll be back in a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can stay for two weeks.   I don't care. She's got a toughness Creasy likes.   As she looks out th window, he looks ahead. Work in Progress 2/10/03

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creasy eats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The food is excellent, Maria.     You have a real talent. Maria beams with pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My pleasure, Creasy. Pinta enters  in a RED SATIN DEVIL'S OUTFIT. She looks a bit forlorn  as she sits at opposite ends of the table from Creasy.   As she stares at her plate, Creasy starts to laugh at  what an odd sight she is. All dressed up and no place to  go. Wrong move. Pinta stands, marches out of the room. Maria and Creasy exchange a look...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pinta the devil stares sadly out here window. Then there it is! The macaw. Sitting on the opposite roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pinta pushes it open, climbs out onto the slope of the roof. This doesn't look like such a good idea. As she crosses, disappears over the peak. It's a game of catch me if you can. 'Bird' looks at Pinta right in the eye. She gingerly moves closer. The bird moves away, just out of her reach each time.

dialogues.speaker: CHIMNEY
dialogues.text: Pinta coming down the other slope.      There's the macaw

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.   Come on.   Bird! The fourth time Pinta's fingers are centimeters away. She reaches and suddenly slides along the slick tile covering this section of the roof. Frank's in the yard barking loudly. Near the edge, she manages to stop.      Whew! She scrambles up a few feet. A tile snaps off. She slides again. This time right off the edge. Work in Progress 2/10/03 She catches the rain gutter. Hangs thirty feet above the ground. A concrete landing below. As the gutter creaks:

dialogues.speaker: CREASY
dialogues.text: Creasy is on his feet, out the door in a heartbeat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creasy dashes around just as the gutter drops on one side. Pinta drops ten feet, jerks to a stop as the gutter stops, then drops the last twenty feet... ...landing in a hedge.   Creasy dashes over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pinta! She's in a lot of pain, but moving her arms and head. Frank's licking her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It hurts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Short)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everywhere! She puts her hands to the left side of her ribs.     Crea carefully probes with his fingers. She winces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think they're broken.     Anywhere else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My ankle. As Maria huffs and puffs her way up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to get you out, okay? Pinta nods. Creasy eases his arms under, around her, lifts her out as gently as possible. She disappears in his arms. Work in Progress 2/10/03

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Creasy... And she bursts into tears. Maria looks up at the thirty foot fall. Begins to cross herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay.    She's just scared. Creasy cradles her, pats her back.      As Pinta says his name like a mantra...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa on the phone. Fantastic in a black evening dress. The Ford car industry dinner awaits her entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sure she's alright? Samuel enters from the bathroom, concern on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, good,   you're sure. (to   Samuel)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He took her   for an X-ray, but it's just a bruise and   a sprain. She turns her back so Samuel can zip her dress up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Creasy.      Give her my love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creasy makes his way up, enters...

dialogues.speaker: PINTA'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Pinta in bed propped up by a pillow, teddy bear beside her. Frank at the head of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The night you arrived, Mom asked you if you had a family and you lied, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: White lie. I didn't have a family. But I did have two kids. They're adults now. It's a sensitive subject so Pinta moves on.      She nods Creasy looks at the bear. An odd beat. Work in Progress 2/10/03

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you always sleep with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm too old for him.     Don't tell my friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't talk to them much.     Does he have a name? Pinta thinks just a beat, then shakes her head 'no'. Liar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I spoke to your mother.     She sends her love. Pinta nods. Creasy stands there a beat, then heads for the door. Almost out, he looks back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some bodyguard I turned out to be.       Good night, Pinta. He's halfway out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creasy?   Could you play the song? Creasy is confused a moment, but when he sees her open window, he realizes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Bayou.   You got it. He goes.   As Pinta eases back with a sigh and a smile...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pedro the 'car wash guy' puts the finishing touches to the Mercedes. Using crutches, Pinta hobbles over. Creasy opens the back door for her. But when she gets there, she hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'll sit in the front.     There's more room for my foot. Creasy makes no big deal of it. He takes her crutches, opens the front. As she scoots inside... Frank waits and watches. Creasy calls to him. Work in Progress 2/10/03

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's only allowed to travel in the car on weekends. Dad says the car will smell 'doggie'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both of them up front. Pinta is happy to be there and Creasy doesn't seem to mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you sleep alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's the ankle? Can you put your weight on it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's   not too bad. Will it take a long time   before it's better? Our big swim meet   is in three weeks. Interschools. I was   going to swim in the one hundred meter   freestyle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a week you should be fine. They drive on a few silent beats, until...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't matter. I always finish second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need to practice. Pinta looks at him hopefully, but Creasy catches himself. He's not going to coach a little girl. Finally...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gomez, Maria and Creasy again joined by Pinta.    As Crea places a fork of meat into his mouth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creasy, what's a concubine? Creasy opens his mouth, takes the fork of meat back out. Work in Progress 2/10/03

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you ask?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was in a book at school.   Concubine. Maria and Gomez wait to see how he'll answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's a sort of wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the Emperor of China had 1000 of them! How can that be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the West, it's one wife for one husband, but different cultures have different rules.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It must be difficult having lots of wives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You feel sorry for the husband?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Can you imagine my mother multiplied by a thousand? Maria and Gomez burst out laughing. So funny that Creasy smiles. Pinta lights up at the sight. A huge victory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creasy, you're smiling. He reverts to a frown. Now Pinta bursts out laughing. And Creasy can't help but smile again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I am. Pinta changes subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how come you know so much about those countries?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had to do my homework on them when I worked there. Also I enjoy history. Work in Progress 2/10/03

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you do in Asia? Is that where you met the man with cigarettes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that was in Columbia.

dialogues.speaker: GOMEZ
dialogues.text: Humming to himself as he brushes the leaves out of the empty SWIMMING POOL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU of a water faucet unloads 100 gallons a minute. A MAN'S HAND.   BLACK. Raises up against the blue sky. Like a kid playing Cowboys and Indians. The finger pulls an imaginary trigger.

dialogues.speaker: RAMOS POOL
dialogues.text: In her swimsuit and cap, Pinta crouches in makeshift starting blocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bang! Pinta takes off. Splashes into the water.     Not to Creasy's satisfaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, come back. Pinta turns in the water, looks back at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't flinch when a gun goes off; you react. You go. Don't listen for the sound; don't anticipate it. Concentrate on the sound itself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry.    You will. Creasy points at the blocks.    Pinta gets out of the water. Work in Progress 2/10/03 Shivering, Creasy throws a towel around her and rubs her down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the way to school. Pinta is stealing looks at Creasy's right hand. She knows the answer must be serious, but she has to ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creasy, what happened to your hand? Creasy looks at her a moment, deciding. Pinta practically holds her breath, watches him, knows the answer may come. Creasy checks the mirror, watches the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man asked me questions once.   He smoked a lot. There was no ashtray. That's it. End of explanation. Creasy continues watching the road. Pinta watches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember you asked me what state I was from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you're from isn't so much about geography; it's about events. Where you're from is what happened to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good things happen, too, Creasy. (smiles big)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like meeting me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess that really does make me a hard case. As the two of them share a LAUGH...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa walking toward Creasy's room. As she moves to knock, she sees the door is ajar, hears voices. She peeks in. Work in Progress 2/10/03 Creasy and Pinta sit on the floor, pencils, papers and a book spread out before them. Doing her history homework.

dialogues.speaker: OF CREASY
dialogues.text: He's charming and great with Pinta.     And sexy... Evely was right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a girlfriend, Creasy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you used to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   Two or three. Lisa continues to watch the little play. She smiles, knocks on the door as she opens it. Pinta and Creasy both look back over their shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creasy, tomorrow, after you drop off Pinta, could you come back to take me to get my hair done? Creasy nods. They both continue to look at her.      She gets the feeling she's interrupting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, I'll leave you two to your history. As she goes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mexico City traffic is heavy. Cars and people. Creasy stands by the car across the street. Cooling his heels. He can just catch a glimpse of Lisa in the shop. Suddenly the traffic seems to finish, expending itself. The street goes ominously quiet. Creasy's antennae go up. A police car comes prowling down the empty street. Creasy makes eye contact with the guys up front. Then, Creasy spots a BUSINESSMAN coming out of a doorway with a BODYGUARD attached. The bodyguard is speaking into a two-way radio. Work in Progress 2/10/03 Creasy's sixth sense tweaks as a Mercedes 500 pulls up to collect the businessman. And the cop car disappears around the corner even as TWO MEN start toward the businessman. Lisa exits the hairdresser's.    Looks stunning. Creasy starts across the street toward her. A second car squeals around the corner behind the Mercedes and everything goes to Hell. GUNFIRE erupts. And then Creasy is there. His arm around Lisa's waist, sweeping her off her feet. The next thing she knows she flattened on the ground in a shop doorway, Creasy on top of her. Shielding her. The bodyguard beside the businessman is killed. The body guard in the Mercedes trades a full magazine before he's shot. A PEDESTRIAN is killed. Liza screams as the glass above and behind them shatters. The businessman is hustled into the back of the second car. Lisa sees the gun in Creasy's hands. She hears the slamming of the car door, the screeching of tires. A parked VAN also hauling ass out of there. But then she's aware of something else. Creasy on top of her.   She feels his weight, his heat...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't move. She watches as he rises, goes to the curb. One bodyguard is sprawled dead across the ground. Red blood on the sidewalk. As Lisa closes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa sits in the backseat. Through the window we can see Creasy wrap up his statement to a member of the JUDICIAL POLICE. Finally he gets in the car, starts to drive. Work in Progress 2/10/03

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murdering people in the street... You had your gun, why didn't you shoot them? The shoulders in front of her just shrug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing to do with me. Or you. Besides, there was another one in the passenger side of the van with a sawed-off shotgun. If I'd started shooting his friends, he would've had me. And you. Quiet a beat. Lisa pulls a sliver of glass from her hair, looks from it to Creasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A minimum close protection team consists of four men for high threat targets and environments. Even in a low threat situation, you need two guards plus a security trained driver. She shakes involuntarily. It's hitting her.      As they make eye contact through the mirror...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mercedes parked. Creasy and Lisa up against it. Fucking. No cultured way to put it. Like animals. A primal release for both of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pinta waiting alone. Creasy's late. Then the gate swings back; the Mercedes drives through. Smiling, she hurries over, hops in the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (happy to see him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were never late before, I was worried. Creasy doesn't answer.    He actually looks guilty.   Pin watches him a moment. Work in Progress 2/10/03

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's my mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dropped her at home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's no wonder you're late.      Why didn't she just come with you? Creasy doesn't answer, just grunts. Pinta keeps looking at him and it suddenly all makes sense. He looks over at her, starts to say something, then thinks better of it. Finally...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think my mother likes you? She's for sure pissed. Definitely aware and definitely jealous. Creasy's a bit amazed, not sure how to respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think she's afraid of me.      But not the same way most people are. Pinta considers this.   Then..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not afraid you, Creasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you're not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you afraid of me? Creasy looks at her, almost like he's deciding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to be.     At first.   But not anymore. Her smile is huge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heated. Steam rising off the water. PINTA stands with her eyes closed. Creasy, standing beside her, brings TWO BLOCKS together with a WHACK! Work in Progress 2/10/03 Pinta flinches at the sound. She opens her eyes, shrugs an apology at him. Creasy frowns, shakes his head. Pinta closes her eyes again. He starts walking around her. Frank oversees the whole program.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gunshot holds no fear.    Say it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gunshot holds no fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You welcome the sound. The sound is what lets you go. The sound is what frees you. You are a prisoner in those blocks until you hear the sound. Eyes closed, she's drifted off with his voice. And Creasy WHACKS them together right in front of her face. Pinta smiles at the sound.     Creasy smiles at the sight

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHACK!   Pinta bolts from the blocks.    SPLASHES. WHACK! WHACK! WHACK! Pinta surges.      Pinta arcs.    Pi knifes into the water. Pinta touches the far wall of the pool, the finish line. Creasy checks his watch, claps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm tough, Creasy.    I'm tough as you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no such thing as tough.    You're either trained or untrained. Pinta raises her arms overhead, makes like Rocky across the shallow end. Creasy shakes his head in amusement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First light is just tracing outlines against the window. Lisa alone in bed, staring at the ceiling. Frightened at what she's feeling.

dialogues.speaker: CREASY
dialogues.text: Sleeping, looking sexy. Work in Progress 2/10/03

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Mercedes pulls in, another car is ahead of it. Samuel is home, a DRIVER pulls his LUGGAGE from the trunk. Pinta gets out of the Mercedes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Dad. He gives her a pat on the head. Simultaneously, Samuel fixes Creasy with a look, strides purposefully over. He thrusts out his hand, shakes Creasy's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to thank you, Creasy.   For what you did for my wife. Creasy wants to choke, but he just nods, looks past Samuel to Pinta who looks bemused. He doesn't even want to know exactly what she knows. The Car Wash Guy, - Pedro, ingratiates himself with Samuel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creasy's finger presses play. "Blue Bayou" begins. Plaintive, haunting. As he moves to sit in his chair, he passes the scotch bottle. It has gone unopened. He ejects the shell from the breach of the 9mm, smoothly catches it on the back of his hand. Rock steady. Frank's tail wags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the song drifts down. Pinta smiles, closes her eyes. Now she can go to sleep. INT.   LISA & SAMUEL'S ROOM - NIGHT Samuel makes love to his wife. But Lisa looks past him, through the walls and floors to where that song plays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going back someday, come what may, to Blue Bayou. Work in Progress 2/10/03

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU of Creasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The big swim meet. Race day. A lot of security, men speaking into their wrists. For a public gathering the mood almost seems ominous. Creasy and Pinta exit the Mercedes. Pinta watches wistfully as her fellow STUDENTS stream toward the water with their PARENTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's so important in Los Angeles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father has business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why today?    And why'd she have to go with him? Creasy shrugs. No comforting answer for her.     He looks around at some of the other bodyguards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck. I'll be waiting here when you're done. But she's shaking her head adamantly.    Determined.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're coming with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big MARQUEE has been set up alongside the pool. Coltish girls in swimsuits. Parents socialize, drink cocktails. Richly dressed. Bodyguards and security are outside of it, on the perimeter. Creasy looks completely out of place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand near the finish line. Pinta starts away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pinta. She turns, looks back at him. Work in Progress 2/10/03

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles; knows)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a prisoner in them.    Until the gunshot sets me free. Creasy nods. He smiles. He's serious now. As he watches her head off for the track, Sister Anna steps up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Creasy, nice to see you. And now Creasy is completely out of place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (apologetic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pinta's parents are in Los Angeles.      I was going to wait in the courtyard, but... She takes his arm, pats his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today you are her father. As Creasy lets this sink   in, looks out where Pinta is warming up. Sister  Anna   smiles, heads off to a group o parents. We're left  with   Creasy. Confused Creasy. But clarity is creeping in.    As the sky opens up around him...

dialogues.speaker: STARTER'S PISTOL
dialogues.text: Pointed up at precisely 45 degrees.    BAAAANGG!

dialogues.speaker: STARTING BLOCKS
dialogues.text: Eyes closed serenely, Pinta surges forward, leaving everyone behind.

dialogues.speaker: CREASY
dialogues.text: Sees it. She hasn't even hit the water and he already knows she's won.

dialogues.speaker: PINTA
dialogues.text: SPLASH! Ten meters in before she breaks the surface. Her head sweeping left and then right. Work in Progress 2/10/03 Wherever her competitors are, it's somewhere behind her. And the future, everything ahead, is wide open.

dialogues.speaker: TURN WALL
dialogues.text: Pinta somersaults, kicks off and is gone.

dialogues.speaker: SURFACE
dialogues.text: And the finish line seems to come to her.

dialogues.speaker: THE CROWD
dialogues.text: Cheers enthusiastically as she reaches the finish wall.
